Comment: I’m an abundance person who desperately wants more housing in CA and I have 3 responses:  First, even if you’re 100% right, I think you should still support the deregulation. Right now, I, and many others, think you’re wrong about where the bottleneck is. However, if all the governmental barriers to new infill housing disappear and blackrock buys them all up and housing prices keep on their current trend, then I’ll admit my error, reconsider  my position, and start backing the laws you propose.  Second, even if you’re 100% right, I don’t see how the deregulation would be a disaster. Suppose blackrock does buy up all the new housing. They’ll be spending money locally, which will benefit the local economy and then paying property taxes to local municipalities which can fund more of the services that you and I both want to provide. If the homes are empty then there won’t be any new people competing for those services and they go completely towards current residents. Win-win.  Third, suppose that you are wrong - deregulation happens, more housing gets built, and prices go down. Surely you admit that there’s a greater-than-zero chance that this is the case? So as I see it, there's only upside to deregulating and no downside. Worst case scenario seems to be that blackrock transfers money to developers, but even then, there are positive local externalities.
